results.title: Anywhere and here [installation suite]
results.brief_description:
‘anywhere and here’ is a suite of five interconnected kinetic sculptures which generate their own real-time video. It specifically explores the road movie genre, summoning familiar visions of the empty landscape, the wide open road and the car-in-motion, to destabilise powerful cinematic clichés.

‘anywhere and here’ was commissioned by ACMI and was exhibited at ACMI as “Ian Burns: In the Telling” in 2012-13.

Burns adapts existing appliances and domestic items and gives them new functions within his sculptures. This work draws meaning from the contrast between the projected image and the machinery out of which it is made.

The five sculptures that make up this work are linked via a video control system constructed by Burns and designed to switch between each of the structures at random. The images that are produced by the sculptures are projected onto the wall for the audience to view. Each scene generates its own live soundtrack. Burns has hacked an electronic keyboard to plunk out a simple music track. The keyboard becomes an integral part of the sculpture.

A shot of the moon suspended over water is based around a glass top table. The resulting optic effect simulates water movement and sparkle. A strip of plywood simulates the sky at dusk, while the moon is created by the projection of light through a hole in the wood.

On one end of a folding table the effect of a smoking chimney is generated using a plastic salad bowl with a LED light inside shining through a slit cut in the backing of a picture frame. The view from the camera is across a roll of hobby store brick print paper.

On the other end of the folding table, to simulate a high zoom shot of a plane passing overhead, Burns rotates a party store plastic salad bowl while a LED light inside the bowl generates the cloud effect. A fan usually used as a cooling device for a computer, generates the sound of the jet and shakes the camera to simulate the zoom effect on a hand-held camera.

A black vinyl chair has been stripped of all its vinyl until only a narrowing strip remains with slots cut out of it. The camera view of this under a red light gives it the look of a remote roadway in dry country.

The shot in close-up of a wheel with the white stripes of the road whizzing past is a road movie cliché. The sculpture is constructed out of an actual car wheel on a treadmill and a camera positioned to catch a cinematic view of the action.

The fifth sculpture comprises the central electronic system that guides the work as a whole.

results.title: Anyway...what is an Australian?
results.creator_credit: Barbara Boyd and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: Views the concept of multiculturalism through the eyes of several Australians in multicultural Melbourne. Through these people’s lives, the most typical element of Australian society is seen to be a continuing pattern of cultural interchange. A spectrum of ideas, attitudes and values which reflect the diversity of opinions, traditions and life-styles current among the Australian population. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Anything you want to be
results.brief_description: A tongue-in-cheek history of a girl who could be anything she wanted - but her parents gave her dolls. In High School she decided to stand for class president but had to settle for being secretary. Vocational guidance placed her in nursing, rather than medicine. She then tried sports but a boy beat her. While developing her mind, she read cookbooks. Finally, she decided to be a woman - whatever that is!

results.title: Anything can happen in life
results.creator_credit: Zenebech Tebeje, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Zenebech Tebeje reflects on growing up in her large family and how quickly life can change. But if you can adapt and embrace your new life, you can do anything.

results.title: Anyplace but here
results.creator_credit: Maurice Murad, Tom Spain and C B S News
results.brief_description: Examines the dilemma facing the mentally ill in America and the people who try to help them. With the advent of stabilising drugs, more patients are returning to the community. However, unless the patients have homes to return to they are released into communities unprepared to either accept or treat them. Follows three patients on their separate paths as they seek their release from a psychiatric centre.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Maurice Murad, Tom Spain and C B S News

results.title: Anyone can be a genius
results.creator_credit: Julian Russell, Channel Communications and Bush Christmas Productions
results.brief_description: This is a film about the meaning of life, about why the human brain is the most extraordinary thing ever created. Sit back and watch the exploding rocket, the eccentric animation, what it means to be a parent, Land Rights, the re-enactment of Archimedes and listen to the 21 original compositions of music. Or look at Latin America in a way you’ve never seen before. Narrated by Noni Hazlehurst.

results.title: Anyone anything anywhere
results.creator_credit: Don Scheldrup, Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
Despite its low profile, the transport element of the Royal Australian Airforce is one of the largest air carriers in Australia. It has both national and international commitments and is capable of delivering anyone, or almost anything, anywhere in the world. Narrated by Peter Gwynne. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Anybody's son will do
results.creator_credit: Paul Cowan, John Kramer, Bill Brind and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “War”.
Offers unusually frank insights into techniques that all armies use to motivate recruits. The film takes us to Parris Island Marine Recruit Training Depot in South Carolina, USA, to observe the rituals that will transform a motley group of eighteen year-olds into soldiers of the United States Marine Corps, unquestionably the roughest, toughest branch in the US military. It is a gripping study of what it takes to change ordinary civilians into the staple of wars, soldiers ready to kill, even to die for their country.
